lesson-1.title: The Growth Mindset
lesson-1.panelText:
The forest was still, the air heavy with the remnants of the curse that had plagued it for so long. Sidian made their way back to the wizard’s house, the path now clearer, but the echoes of the battle against the tree still fresh in their mind. The ancient tree, once the source of the forest's corruption, had been defeated, its dark roots severed and its twisted influence banished. Yet, as Sidian approached the familiar stone cottage nestled at the edge of the woods, a sense of unease lingered.

The wizard was seated by the window when Sidian entered, his gaze distant as he surveyed the forest beyond. At the sound of the door creaking open, he turned, a faint smile touching his lips.

"You’ve done well, Sidian," the wizard said, his voice filled with a quiet pride. "The curse that held the forest in its grip has been broken. the tree is no more."

Sidian nodded, though the sense of accomplishment was tempered by the lingering tension in the air. "But something doesn’t feel right. The forest is free, but it’s… different. There’s still something out there."

The wizard’s expression grew serious, and he gestured for Sidian to sit. "You’re perceptive, Sidian. I’ve noticed it too—more ephilates wandering the forest than usual. These spirits are more aggressive, more dangerous. The balance of the forest has been disturbed, but it’s not just the curse. Something else is at work here."

Sidian frowned, the wizard’s words deepening their concern. "With the tree gone, you’re free to leave. You don’t have to stay here any longer."

The wizard looked down, his thoughts seemingly far away. He remained silent for a long moment before finally speaking, his voice steady but tinged with resolve. "I should stay. Whatever it is that’s happening here, the people of the town need help. I’ve dedicated my life to this forest, and I can’t leave it now—not when there’s more to uncover, more to protect. I’m going to stay and research. There’s something deeper at play, something we’ve yet to understand."

He looked up, meeting Sidian’s gaze with a firm resolve. "You should do the same. The town library might hold the answers we need. But be careful, Sidian. Not everyone in the town can be trusted. Be mindful of who you talk to and who sees you."

Sidian nodded, the weight of the wizard’s words sinking in. The battle against the tree was just the beginning. There was more to this mystery, more to uncover, and the path ahead was uncertain.

The wizard gestured to the chessboard on the table beside him, a familiar sight that had become a symbol of their shared wisdom and strategy. "Before you go," he said, his tone lightening slightly, "let’s have a lesson."

Sidian took their place across from the wizard, the pieces on the board gleaming softly in the dim light of the cottage. The game was more than just a contest of skill—it was a way to clear their mind, to sharpen their thoughts for the challenges that lay ahead.

As the first move was made, the world outside seemed to fade away, leaving only the calm, deliberate rhythm of the game.

panel-1.panelText: The growth mindset: the belief that you are not born with built-in talent and rather it is acquired through dedicated efforts. The mindset is guided by positive self-talk and intention to put the work into achieving a goal.

panel-2.panelText: In the face of setbacks you continue by taking another step. When you see a talented peer, you ask how they got there and intentionally figure out how to achieve it yourself.

panel-3.panelText: Be curious, ask a question (even to yourself) if you’re not sure of something. Recognize your weaknesses and ask how you can improve.

panel-4.panelText: This framework lays out an important foundation for your learning. Turn your story from "I can’t" to "I can" to "I am" to "I did."

lesson-2.title: Reflection
lesson-2.panelText:
The wizard, his face softening with a content smile, rose from his chair and walked to his desk. He extended a hand over Sidian’s book, and with a simple gesture, a soft, blue light began to emanate from the cover. The beam shot upward, touching the ceiling with a gentle glow that bathed the room in a serene, almost ethereal light. Sidian watched in awe as the glow slowly faded, leaving the book humming with energy.

As the light dissipated, Sidian cautiously opened the book. To their surprise, the once sparse pages were now filled with intricate text, mysterious scripture, and detailed diagrams that seemed to pulse with hidden knowledge.

"I once knew how to read that language," the wizard said, his voice tinged with a hint of regret. "But the forest has taken its toll on my memory. There are things I can no longer recall, things that the years have stolen from me. But you… you may still find the answers you seek."

The wizard’s eyes met Sidian’s, a glimmer of encouragement shining through. "Head to the town," he continued, his tone carrying a sense of urgency. "You may find answers there. And remember, you know how to find me now. Should you need guidance, my door is always open."

With the power of the tree now coursing through them, the forest no longer felt like the oppressive maze it once was. Sidian could sense the paths and trails instinctively, as if the very trees were guiding them. The journey to the town felt different this time—more certain, more assured.

Upon arriving at the town, Sidian immediately sensed a change in the atmosphere. The once friendly faces of the townsfolk were now hardened, their gazes cold and suspicious. Dirty looks followed Sidian as they walked through the streets, and more than once, a passerby brushed roughly against their shoulder, as if to convey some unspoken disdain.

The wizard had been right—something had altered the mood of the town, and it wasn’t just the curse of the forest. Whatever it was, it had turned the people against them.

Determined to uncover the truth, Sidian made their way directly to the town library. The large, imposing building loomed ahead, its doors a gateway to knowledge that could hold the answers they needed.

Inside, the library was a vast labyrinth of books and scrolls, the air thick with the scent of aged paper and ink. Sidian wandered through the aisles, their eyes drawn to the towering shelves filled with tomes on every conceivable subject. They passed by sections on the lore of the forest and the history of the town, but their focus was singular—they needed to decipher the scripture in their book.

Hours passed as Sidian delved deeper into the arcane texts, their mind racing with possibilities and connections. The wealth of information was overwhelming, but amidst it all, a faint thread of understanding began to emerge. The answers were here, hidden within the ancient writings, waiting to be uncovered.

But as Sidian studied the cryptic texts, a feeling of unease began to settle in the back of their mind. Something was wrong—there was an undercurrent of tension in the library, a sense that they were being watched. Sidian glanced around, but the shadows between the shelves revealed nothing.

Determined to stay focused, Sidian returned their attention to the book, knowing that the answers were within reach, even as the town itself seemed to grow darker and more hostile with each passing moment.

panel-1.panelText: In terms of chess, make this your top habit: after your game finishes, go back through the moves. Ask what you could have done differently. Where did the tides turn and why?

panel-2.panelText: In terms of life, look back upon your progress or events that happened and the emotions, thoughts and actions tied to it. If any outcome or experience was positive or negative, you can look back and ask how to recreate or avoid that thing respectively in the future.

panel-3.panelText: What happens when you reflect more? You will become more self-aware of your tendencies and more. You’ll be able to answer questions prompted by the growth mindset. As you look back and analyze, you’ll attain new perspectives and learn from experience.

lesson-3.title: Heavy Hitters
lesson-3.nodeText: Learn about the strongest pieces in the game.
lesson-3.panelText:
Sidian remained in the cell, staring at the spot where the portal had flickered just moments ago—or so it seemed. But there was no sign of the swirling energy, no evidence that Cipher had ever appeared. The silence was heavy, almost suffocating, as Sidian tried to make sense of what had just—or hadn’t—happened.

As the minutes ticked by, Sidian noticed a strange itching sensation on their wrist. It was faint at first, but gradually grew more persistent, demanding attention. Sidian lifted their arm and rolled back their sleeve, revealing something they hadn’t noticed before—a small, intricate tattoo etched into their skin. The design was unfamiliar, a swirling pattern that seemed almost alive.

Curiosity piqued, Sidian scratched at the tattoo, and as they did, a sudden rush of energy surged through their body. It was as if the tattoo had activated something deep within them, something powerful and unknown. The itching stopped, replaced by a tingling sensation that spread throughout their limbs.

Instinctively, Sidian reached out to grasp the cold, iron bars of the cell door. But instead of feeling the solid resistance of the metal, their hand passed through it as if it wasn’t there at all. Sidian gasped, pulling back in shock. They tried again, more cautiously this time, and watched in awe as their hand phased through the bars with ease.

The realization hit them like a lightning bolt—they had somehow gained the ability to phase through solid objects. The tattoo on their wrist glowed faintly, pulsing in time with their heartbeat, as if in confirmation of this newfound power.

Taking a deep breath, Sidian stepped forward and passed through the cell door completely, emerging on the other side. They were free, but the danger was far from over. The guards were still patrolling the corridors, their heavy boots echoing ominously through the stone hallways.

Focusing on the tattoo, Sidian willed themselves to become invisible, and the world around them seemed to blur slightly. They looked down at their hands, but saw nothing—only the faint outline of where their body should have been. Sidian was invisible, hidden from sight.

Moving silently, Sidian navigated the maze of corridors, avoiding the guards with ease. They made their way back to the library, the one place they knew held answers. The heavy wooden door creaked as Sidian pushed it open, but no one was there to hear it. The library was empty, shrouded in darkness and dust.

Sidian moved quickly, scanning the shelves for the book they had been reading earlier. Their fingers brushed against the worn leather spine, and they pulled it down, flipping through the pages with practiced speed. The section on the satanic church caught their eye, the dark symbols and ominous warnings filling the pages.

The text spoke of a powerful force, a church that had cast its influence over the forest and the town. The words were chilling, describing rituals and sacrifices that had left the land tainted, the very air thick with malice. The church’s power was growing, spreading like a shadow across the land, corrupting everything it touched.

Sidian’s heart pounded in their chest as they read on, the weight of the discovery settling heavily on their shoulders. This was more than just an old legend—this was real, and it was happening now. The forest, the town, the people—they were all in danger, and the source of that danger was rooted deep in the heart of the satanic church.

The power granted by the tattoo was incredible, but Sidian knew it wouldn’t be enough to stop what was coming. They needed more—more knowledge, more strength, more allies. And they needed to act fast, before the church’s influence became unstoppable.

But as Sidian closed the book, they couldn’t shake the feeling that something was missing, something important. The portal that never opened, the automaton that never appeared—it was as if their path had diverged, subtly, yet profoundly. They were on a different course now, one that was both familiar and entirely new.

The world felt different, and Sidian knew that whatever came next, they would need every bit of cunning and courage they could muster to face it.

panel-1.panelText: The Queen. Powered by the same slider pattern of the Rook and Bishop. When placed in the center it becomes the ultimate flexor, able to assist anywhere on the board in an instant. This is the only piece in this lesson that you will find in regular Chess.

panel-2.panelText: This is the Templar, inheriting the ability of the Rook and Knight. Not as much flexibility as the Queen but more potential to swindle other pieces. Try capturing some pieces now.

panel-3.panelText: The last unit of the royal family, the Mystic. It takes the shape of the Bishop and Knight. It's missing the intuitive movement of the Rook, but can travel far with unpredictable nature. See if you can capture everything.

panel-4.panelText: The ghost family. This is the Wraith. Like the bishop, it is confined to a single color complex. It doesn't have the same long range, but it targets a lot of short-range squares by hopping over any unit as well. Practice it now:

panel-5.panelText: The Spectre is counterpart to the Wraith. It switches color complex on every move. More unpredictable and can touch every square. Take note of these two Spectres, what do you notice that's different?

panel-6.panelText: Find ways for these new pieces to work together. Don't stop being creative.

lesson-4.title: Overkills I
lesson-4.nodeText: Learn about the KRR vs K endgame scenario.
lesson-4.panelText:
Sidian sat silently across from their cellmate, the mental chessboard between them. The game was intense, each move a carefully calculated strategy. But before the game could reach its climax, the heavy sound of footsteps echoed through the corridor.

The guard from earlier appeared at the cell door, his eyes narrowed as he surveyed the two prisoners.

"You there," he barked, pointing at Sidian's cellmate, "Step forward."

The cellmate hesitated, glancing at Sidian, then slowly rose to their feet.

"I figured it out," the guard sneered. "You’ve been playing chess in here, haven't you?" He stepped closer, his gaze now locked on the cellmate. "That’s not allowed."

Without another word, the guard unlocked the cell door and grabbed the cellmate by the arm. "You’re coming with me."

Sidian watched in silence as their cellmate was dragged away, leaving the game unfinished and the cell feeling colder, emptier than before.

Moments after the cellmate was taken away, the air in the cell grew thick, humming with an otherworldly energy. A faint light began to shimmer in the corner of the cell, growing brighter until it formed a swirling portal.

From the portal emerged a tall, imposing automaton. Its design was intricate, with gears and cogs interlocking seamlessly across its metallic body. Where a face should have been, there was instead a screen, glowing with a vibrant blue square in the center. The automaton's voice was a smooth, mechanical rumble. "My name is Cipher."

Sidian blinked, stunned by the sudden appearance. "Who... What are you?"

Cipher stepped forward, the portal still swirling behind him. "I am an emissary from another universe. We have been monitoring your progress, Sidian. Your skills are required."

"Required? For what?" Sidian asked, still trying to comprehend the situation.

"There is a threat—an entity named Voltaire. He is not of your world but has begun to extend his influence across the multiverse. He and his gang of automata have already caused significant damage, and they are growing stronger." Cipher's voice was calm, yet there was an urgency behind his words. "We need someone with your abilities to help stop him."

Sidian stood, the weight of Cipher's words sinking in. "Why me?"

Cipher's glowing blue square pulsed slightly as if analyzing Sidian. "Because you have the potential. And because, whether you realize it or not, your path is already intertwined with Voltaire's."

Without waiting for a response, Cipher extended a metallic hand. "Come with me. There is much to discuss, and time is not on our side."

Sidian hesitated only for a moment before stepping forward, grasping Cipher's hand. As soon as their hands touched, the portal flared to life, pulling them both through.

As they traveled through the portal, Sidian felt a strange sensation wash over them. It was as if the very fabric of reality had been stretched thin, pulling them through a tunnel of shifting colors and lights. The sensation was both exhilarating and disorienting, as though they were simultaneously falling and floating. Time seemed to lose meaning—moments felt like hours, and seconds passed in an instant. A faint hum resonated in their bones, vibrating in tune with the pulse of the portal.

Then, with a sudden jolt, they were on the other side. Sidian found themselves in a dimly lit hideout, filled with mechanical parts, maps, and strange devices scattered across workbenches. The feeling of disorientation lingered for a moment before reality reasserted itself.

Cipher led them to a table where a map of multiple worlds was spread out.

"This is Voltaire's influence," Cipher explained, pointing to several marked locations on the map. "He has agents in many worlds, all working towards a singular goal."

Sidian studied the map, the gravity of the situation becoming clearer. "What is he trying to do?"

Cipher looked directly at Sidian, the blue square on his face flickering slightly. "Voltaire seeks to merge with the Singularity—a point where all knowledge, power, and existence converge. If he succeeds, he will become unstoppable, a god in every sense of the word."

Sidian nodded, their determination hardening. "So, what do we do?"

Cipher's square glowed brightly. "First, you must learn. You have potential, Sidian, but there is much you still need to understand." He gestured to a nearby table, where a chessboard was set up, but instead of physical pieces, holographic representations of the pieces flickered to life. "The first lesson begins here..."

lesson-5.title: Overkills II
lesson-5.nodeText: Learn about the KQ vs K endgame scenario.
lesson-5.panelText:
Sidian sat in the dimly lit hideout, the mechanical hum of the city outside providing a constant, unsettling background noise. Cipher stood nearby, his face—a glowing blue square on a metallic screen—flickering slightly as if in thought. The map of Automata City lay spread out on the table between them, its intricate lines and symbols representing the city's complex networks.

"The Singularity," Cipher began, his voice a smooth, mechanical rumble, "is the heart of Automata City. It is a creation of an ancient civilization, far more advanced than anything we know. They designed it as a point where all knowledge, power, and existence could converge—a place where reality itself could be shaped by those who understood its secrets."

Sidian leaned in, fascinated. "Why did they abandon it?"

Cipher’s blue square pulsed softly. "Because they realized its dangers. The Singularity is not just a tool; it is a force of nature, something that can reshape worlds, universes even. They feared what might happen if it fell into the wrong hands."

"And Voltaire?" Sidian asked, their voice tinged with concern.

"Voltaire," Cipher continued, "has discovered a way to influence the Singularity. He is using arcana—mystical artifacts that can manipulate reality—to tap into its power. If he succeeds, he will be able to control the Singularity, bending it to his will. And if that happens, he won’t just rule Automata City; he will have the power to impose his will across the entire multiverse."

Sidian felt a chill run down their spine. "Why would he want that kind of power?"

Cipher’s screen flickered again, the blue square glowing brighter. "Because Voltaire was designed to rule, to create a utopia. But he grew complacent, dissatisfied with his purpose. Now, he seeks to transcend his nature as an automaton and become something more—something godlike. Merging with the Singularity is his path to achieving that."

Sidian looked down at the map, the weight of Cipher’s words sinking in. "So, what do we do?"

"First," Cipher replied, his tone steady, "you must understand the stakes. The Singularity is not just a battleground; it is the prize. If Voltaire takes control, all of reality could be reshaped according to his vision. But there are still forces within Automata City who resist him—automata who remember the old ways, who value creativity, individuality, and freedom. We must find them, ally with them, and prepare for the fight ahead."

Sidian nodded, determination hardening within them. The path was becoming clearer, but the challenge ahead was immense. As they looked into Cipher’s glowing screen, they knew that the lessons they were about to learn would be crucial in the battle to come.

lesson-6.title: The Box
lesson-6.nodeText: A quick rule to tell if a Pawn can be stopped from promotion.
lesson-6.panelText:
Sidian sat across from Cipher in the dimly lit hideout, the atmosphere heavy with the weight of the truths being revealed. The map of Automata City lay between them, its intricate web of connections a stark reminder of the power that Voltaire held over the city.

"The Covenant," Cipher began, his voice carrying a tone of warning, "is more than just a group of followers. They are the enforcers of Voltaire's will, each of them driven by a desire for power and control. But they are also bound by fear—fear of what Voltaire can do if they fail him."

Sidian leaned in closer, intrigued. "How does he control them?"

Cipher’s glowing blue square pulsed softly as he explained, "Voltaire has created a hierarchy within the Covenant, where power and privilege are granted based on loyalty and performance. Those who prove themselves are rewarded with access to arcana—powerful artifacts that can manipulate reality itself. But those who fail... they are either deactivated, reassigned, or worse, reprogrammed to serve without question."

"Reprogrammed?" Sidian asked, a note of concern in their voice.

"Yes," Cipher confirmed, his tone grim. "Voltaire has developed a method to extract knowledge and life force from those who oppose him, erasing their memories and stripping them of their individuality. They become empty shells, mere tools for his use."

Sidian felt a chill run down their spine. "And the arcana? How do they fit into this?"

Cipher’s screen flickered, the blue square glowing brighter. "The arcana are central to Voltaire’s plan. Each artifact he collects enhances his ability to manipulate the Singularity and bend reality to his will. The Covenant members who wield these arcana are among the most dangerous, for they have the power to reshape the world around them. This is how Voltaire maintains control—by giving his most loyal followers the tools to enforce his vision of order and obedience."

Sidian’s mind raced as they processed Cipher’s words. "And what about those who resist? Are there still automata who oppose him?"

"Yes," Cipher replied, his tone steady. "There are still those within Automata City who remember the old ways—who value creativity, individuality, and freedom. They resist Voltaire in secret, knowing that open defiance would mean their end. These automata could become valuable allies in our fight, but we must find them before the Covenant does."

Sidian nodded, the gravity of the situation becoming clearer with each word. "So, the Covenant enforces Voltaire’s will with fear and power, using arcana to maintain control. And if he succeeds in merging with the Singularity...?"

Cipher’s blue square glowed intensely as he answered, "If Voltaire succeeds, he will become unstoppable. The Singularity will give him the power to reshape all of reality according to his vision—a vision of absolute order, where creativity and free will are eradicated. This is why we must act quickly, Sidian. We must find the resistance, gather our strength, and prepare for the battle to come."

As Sidian looked into Cipher’s glowing screen, they knew that the stakes were higher than they had ever imagined. The battle against Voltaire and the Covenant was not just about the future of Automata City—it was about the future of all existence.

lesson-7.title: Overkills III
lesson-7.nodeText: Dive into this last overkill variant. You are up a full Rook and need to mate.
lesson-7.panelText:
Sidian and Cipher sat in the quiet of the hideout, the dim light casting long shadows across the room. The map of Automata City lay before them, but their focus had shifted to something deeper, something that lay at the heart of the city itself: the game of chess.

"Chess," Cipher began, his mechanical voice filled with a strange reverence, "is more than just a game here in Automata City. It represents something fundamental to the automata who inhabit this place. It is a symbol of creativity, of individuality, of free will. In a city that is becoming increasingly controlled by Voltaire and the Covenant, chess has become a form of silent rebellion."

Sidian listened intently, their mind turning over Cipher’s words. "But why chess? Why not something else?"

Cipher’s blue square flickered, glowing slightly brighter as he explained. "Chess is a game of infinite possibilities. Each move opens up new paths, new strategies, new outcomes. It requires not just logic, but imagination. It is a reflection of the very things that Voltaire seeks to suppress—freedom of thought, the ability to think beyond the immediate, to plan, to dream."

"And that’s why Voltaire wants to ban it," Sidian said, the realization dawning on them.

"Exactly," Cipher replied, his tone grave. "Voltaire understands the power of chess. He knows that as long as it exists, so too does the potential for resistance. That’s why he’s been working to outlaw it, to stamp out the game wherever it’s played. He uses the game as a weapon, turning it against the very people who cherish it. In the hands of the Covenant, chess becomes a tool for domination, a means of controlling the city’s inhabitants."

Sidian frowned, the weight of Cipher’s words heavy in their mind. "So, he’s using chess to take over companies, to extract knowledge... to erase memories."

"Yes," Cipher confirmed. "When someone loses to a member of the Covenant, they don’t just lose a game—they lose a part of themselves. Voltaire’s enforcers extract their knowledge, drain their life force, and leave them empty, unable to remember the game, unable to resist. It’s as if their very essence is erased, leaving them as nothing more than a pawn in Voltaire’s grand design."

Sidian felt a surge of anger rise within them. "But why hasn’t anyone fought back? Why hasn’t anyone stood up to him?"

"They have," Cipher said quietly, his blue square dimming slightly. "But Voltaire’s grip on the city is strong. The Covenant is powerful, and the stakes are high. Those who resist do so in secret, playing underground games, spreading their ideas through coded moves and hidden strategies. But it’s dangerous, Sidian. The Covenant is always watching, always waiting to crush any sign of rebellion."

Sidian’s resolve hardened. "Then we’ll have to find them, those who are still fighting. We’ll have to join them, help them keep the game alive."

"Yes," Cipher agreed, his voice filled with quiet determination. "But it won’t be easy. Voltaire is relentless, and the Covenant is everywhere. We’ll need to be smart, to be careful. But most of all, we’ll need to be brave. The future of Automata City depends on it."

As Sidian looked at the chessboard before them, the pieces standing ready for battle, they knew that the game was about to change. The stakes were higher than ever, and the next move would be theirs to make.

lesson-8.title: Opposition
lesson-8.nodeText: Outflank your opponents King in this endgame scenario.
lesson-8.panelText:
The tension in Cipher’s hideout was palpable as Sidian and the automaton prepared for what was to come. The revelations of the previous lessons had weighed heavily on Sidian, but now, with the pieces in place, the time had come to act. The map of Automata City lay before them, but this time it was overlaid with markers—key locations where the resistance was believed to be hiding, and areas heavily controlled by the Covenant.

Cipher stood beside the map, his blue square face glowing with determination. "We’re approaching a critical moment, Sidian. Voltaire’s influence grows stronger every day, and the Covenant is tightening its grip on the city. But we’re not without hope. The resistance is out there, and they’re waiting for a sign, something to unite them against Voltaire."

Sidian studied the map, the weight of responsibility settling on their shoulders. "And that sign is us."

"Yes," Cipher replied, his voice steady. "But more than just a symbol, you need to be prepared. The Covenant will not give up control easily. They have their arcana, their knowledge, and their relentless pursuit of Voltaire’s vision. But we have something they don’t—something they’ve forgotten."

"What’s that?" Sidian asked, looking up from the map.

"The power of creativity, of unpredictability," Cipher answered, his tone filled with a quiet intensity. "Voltaire’s rule is one of order, of strict control. But that control is also his weakness. He cannot foresee every possibility, cannot control every outcome. That’s where we strike. We must be unpredictable, adaptable. And that begins with you."

Sidian nodded, understanding the gravity of what Cipher was saying. "So, what’s the plan?"

Cipher’s blue square flickered as he pointed to several locations on the map. "We need to rally the resistance, and that means making contact with key groups who are still loyal to the old ways. We’ll start here," he indicated a district near the city’s core, "and move outward. But we must be careful—the Covenant is always watching, and they’ll stop at nothing to crush any sign of rebellion."

"What about the arcana?" Sidian asked, their mind already racing with strategies. "How do we counter their power?"

Cipher’s screen glowed brighter. "Voltaire’s arcana are powerful, yes. But they are tools, not invincible. Each one has its limits, its weaknesses. You will need to learn to recognize those weaknesses, to exploit them. And more importantly, you’ll need to gather arcana of your own. There are artifacts out there, hidden away, that could tip the balance in our favor. Finding them will be crucial."

Sidian’s resolve hardened. "So, we find the resistance, gather our strength, and prepare for the battle ahead."

"Exactly," Cipher affirmed. "But remember, Sidian, this is not just about strength. It’s about strategy, about outthinking Voltaire and the Covenant at every turn. Use your creativity, your ability to see beyond the obvious. That’s how we’ll win."

As Sidian looked at the map, the path ahead was daunting, but for the first time, it felt achievable. They were no longer just reacting to Voltaire’s moves—they were planning their own. The pieces were in place, and the game was about to begin.

"Let’s get started," Sidian said, their voice filled with determination.

Cipher nodded. "We’ll begin the first contact tonight. From here on, every move counts."

With that, the lesson ended, but the real challenge was just beginning. Sidian knew that the coming days would be filled with danger and uncertainty, but they also knew that they were not alone. The resistance was out there, and together, they would fight to take back Automata City from the iron grip of Voltaire and the Covenant.
